title: 111_hr1763
content: The "Responsible Reinvestment Act of 2009" includes provisions such as making estate tax repeal permanent and increasing expensing for small businesses. The "Responsible Reinvestment Act of 2009" includes amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, increasing the dollar limitation to $500,000 and the phaseout beginning at $500,000. Inflation adjustments are made by removing references to specific years and dollar amounts. The revocation of election clause is also amended. The "Responsible Reinvestment Act of 2009" amends the Internal Revenue Code by increasing the dollar limitation to $500,000 and removing specific year references for inflation adjustments. The revocation of election clause is also amended to remove the phrase "and before 2011". These amendments apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2009. SEC. 4. ACCELERATED DEPRECIATION FOR MANUFACTURING AND AGRICULTURAL PROPERTY: The table in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include 1-year depreciation for qualified manufacturing or agricultural property. The amendment adds a definition for "qualified manufacturing or agricultural property" in the tax code, specifying it as tangible personal property used in manufacturing or agriculture. The effective date for these changes applies to property placed in service after the enactment of the Act. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code allows for a deduction based on qualified production activities income and qualified small business income for certain taxable years. The Internal Revenue Code amendment allows for a deduction based on qualified production activities income and qualified small business income for taxable years where the annual average number of employees was 500 or fewer. The Internal Revenue Code amendment allows for a deduction based on qualified production activities income and qualified small business income. Employers under specific sections shall be treated as one taxpayer for tax purposes. A special rule states that a taxpayer won't lose qualified small business status solely due to exceeding 500 employees in a subsequent year, except in the event of an ownership change. The Internal Revenue Code allows for a deduction based on qualified production activities income and qualified small business income. Qualified small business income is defined as the excess income of a qualified small business attributable to the actual conduct of a trade or business within the United States. Qualified small business income is the excess income of a qualified small business attributable to the actual conduct of a trade or business within the United States, excluding passive income and income from certain properties. The text describes various types of income that are excluded from qualified small business income, including income from owning or managing a professional sports team, income from specific types of businesses, and income from properties requiring record maintenance under a specific code. Allocation rules from subsection (c) also apply. The amendments made by this section, including a conforming amendment to Section 199(a)(2) of the Code, shall apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2008. SEC. 6. Small business modifications related to health insurance, health savings accounts, and simplified employee pensions. Small business modifications include allowing health insurance deductions and health savings account contributions in determining self-employment tax. Simplified employee pensions also see an increase in the deduction limitation. Simplified Employee Pensions see an increase in the deduction limitation and modifications on contributions for determining self-employment tax. The amendment allows for a deduction for amounts paid to a simplified employee pension. Effective for taxable years after the enactment of the Act.
